title: 106_hr4115
content: Chapter 23 of title 36, United States Code, is amended to establish the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum and outline its functions, council membership, compensation, administrative provisions, staff, insurance, gifts, annual report, audit of financial transactions, and authorization of appropriations. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum is an independent establishment of the US government. It is responsible for commemorating the Days of Remembrance, maintaining a memorial museum for Holocaust victims, and implementing recommendations from the President's Commission on the Holocaust. "SEC. 2302. FUNCTIONS OF THE COUNCIL; MEMBERSHIP." The United States Holocaust Memorial Council is the board of trustees of the Museum with overall governance responsibility, including policy guidance, oversight of operations, and fiduciary duties. The Council consists of 65 voting members appointed by the President, along with ex officio nonvoting members appointed by various Secretaries. The United States Holocaust Memorial Council consists of 65 voting members appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. Council members serve 5-year terms, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The United States Holocaust Memorial Council appoints members to fill vacancies for the remainder of the term. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are appointed by the President for 5-year terms and can be reappointed. The Council adopts bylaws to carry out its functions. The Council adopts bylaws to carry out its functions, with the Chairperson having the authority to waive a bylaw if in the Council's best interest. A quorum is constituted by one-third of Council members, and vacancies do not affect the Council's powers. Non-members can be appointed to associated committees by the Chairperson at no cost to the Federal Government. "SEC. 2303. COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES; FULL-TIME OFFICERS OR EMPLOYEES OF UNITED STATES OR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS." Members of the Council are authorized to be paid the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for positions at level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing Council duties. Full-time officers or employees of the United States or Members of Congress serving on the Council will not receive additional pay. Administrative provisions are outlined in Section 2304. The Museum may obtain experts and consultants at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. It can enter contracts with public agencies and private entities, and receive assistance from other federal departments and agencies. The Secretary of the Interior can provide administrative services and support to the Museum on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 2305. STAFF. The Museum Director, appointed by the Council, serves as the chief executive officer and has the authority to appoint employees in the competitive service. The Museum Director appointed by the Council has the authority to appoint employees, fix their compensation, and implement decisions and strategic plans approved by the Council. The Museum is required to maintain insurance for the memorial museum and determine the coverage needed. Additionally, provisions are made for gifts, bequests, and devises of property with specified tax treatment. The Museum can accept gifts, bequests, and devises of property to support its operation and maintenance. These funds are not considered appropriated funds and are not subject to restrictions. Property accepted is treated as a gift to the United States for tax purposes. The Director must provide an annual report to Congress on the financial transactions, objectives met, future endeavors, and federal funding of the memorial museum. Additionally, there is a requirement for an audit of financial transactions. The Museum's financial transactions, including donated funds, will be audited by the Comptroller General as requested by Congress. The audit will be conducted in accordance with auditing standards, with full access to all relevant records and documents. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the purposes of this chapter, with funds available as needed. No funds can be used for construction. Contracts and payments can only be made as specified in advance in appropriations Acts.
